question: A colleague handed over a Google Cloud Platform project for you to maintain. As part of a security checkup, you want to review who has been granted the ProjectOwner role. What should you do?

A.answer: In the console, validate which SSH keys have been stored as project-wide keys.

B.answer: Navigate to Identity-Aware Proxy and check the permissions for these resources.

C.answer: Enable Audit Logs on the IAM & admin page for all resources, and validate the results.

D.answer: Use the command gcloud projects getג€"iamג€"policy to view the current role assignments.

question: You are running multiple VPC-native Google Kubernetes Engine clusters in the same subnet. The IPs available for the nodes are exhausted, and you want to ensure that the clusters can grow in nodes when needed. What should you do?

A.answer: Create a new subnet in the same region as the subnet being used.

B.answer: Add an alias IP range to the subnet used by the GKE clusters.

C.answer: Create a new VPC, and set up VPC peering with the existing VPC.

D.answer: Expand the CIDR range of the relevant subnet for the cluster.

question: You have a batch workload that runs every night and uses a large number of virtual machines (VMs). It is fault-tolerant and can tolerate some of the VMs being terminated. The current cost of VMs is too high. What should you do?

A.answer: Run a test using simulated maintenance events. If the test is successful, use preemptible N1 Standard VMs when running future jobs.

B.answer: Run a test using simulated maintenance events. If the test is successful, use N1 Standard VMs when running future jobs.

C.answer: Run a test using a managed instance group. If the test is successful, use N1 Standard VMs in the managed instance group when running future jobs.

D.answer: Run a test using N1 standard VMs instead of N2. If the test is successful, use N1 Standard VMs when running future jobs.

question: You are working with a user to set up an application in a new VPC behind a firewall. The user is concerned about data egress. You want to configure the fewest open egress ports. What should you do?

A.answer: Set up a low-priority (65534) rule that blocks all egress and a high-priority rule (1000) that allows only the appropriate ports.

B.answer: Set up a high-priority (1000) rule that pairs both ingress and egress ports.

C.answer: Set up a high-priority (1000) rule that blocks all egress and a low-priority (65534) rule that allows only the appropriate ports.

D.answer: Set up a high-priority (1000) rule to allow the appropriate ports.

question: Your company runs its Linux workloads on Compute Engine instances. Your company will be working with a new operations partner that does not use GoogleAccounts. You need to grant access to the instances to your operations partner so they can maintain the installed tooling. What should you do?

A.answer: Enable Cloud IAP for the Compute Engine instances, and add the operations partner as a Cloud IAP Tunnel User.

B.answer: Tag all the instances with the same network tag. Create a firewall rule in the VPC to grant TCP access on port 22 for traffic from the operations partner to instances with the network tag.

C.answer: Set up Cloud VPN between your Google Cloud VPC and the internal network of the operations partner.

D.answer: Ask the operations partner to generate SSH key pairs, and add the public keys to the VM instances.

question: You have created a code snippet that should be triggered whenever a new file is uploaded to a Cloud Storage bucket. You want to deploy this code snippet. What should you do?

A.answer: Use App Engine and configure Cloud Scheduler to trigger the application using Pub/Sub.

B.answer: Use Cloud Functions and configure the bucket as a trigger resource.

C.answer: Use Google Kubernetes Engine and configure a CronJob to trigger the application using Pub/Sub.

D.answer: Use Dataflow as a batch job, and configure the bucket as a data source.

question: You have been asked to set up Object Lifecycle Management for objects stored in storage buckets. The objects are written once and accessed frequently for 30 days. After 30 days, the objects are not read again unless there is a special need. The objects should be kept for three years, and you need to minimize cost.What should you do?

A.answer: Set up a policy that uses Nearline storage for 30 days and then moves to Archive storage for three years.

B.answer: Set up a policy that uses Standard storage for 30 days and then moves to Archive storage for three years.

C.answer: Set up a policy that uses Nearline storage for 30 days, then moves the Coldline for one year, and then moves to Archive storage for two years.

D.answer: Set up a policy that uses Standard storage for 30 days, then moves to Coldline for one year, and then moves to Archive storage for two years.

question: You are storing sensitive information in a Cloud Storage bucket. For legal reasons, you need to be able to record all requests that read any of the stored data. You want to make sure you comply with these requirements. What should you do?

A.answer: Enable the Identity Aware Proxy API on the project.

B.answer: Scan the bucket using the Data Loss Prevention API.

C.answer: Allow only a single Service Account access to read the data.

D.answer: Enable Data Access audit logs for the Cloud Storage API.

question: You are the team lead of a group of 10 developers. You provided each developer with an individual Google Cloud Project that they can use as their personal sandbox to experiment with different Google Cloud solutions. You want to be notified if any of the developers are spending above $500 per month on their sandbox environment. What should you do?

A.answer: Create a single budget for all projects and configure budget alerts on this budget.

B.answer: Create a separate billing account per sandbox project and enable BigQuery billing exports. Create a Data Studio dashboard to plot the spending per billing account.

C.answer: Create a budget per project and configure budget alerts on all of these budgets.

D.answer: Create a single billing account for all sandbox projects and enable BigQuery billing exports. Create a Data Studio dashboard to plot the spending per project.
